title: CSTI at Plugin page leading to active stored XSS (Publisher name)
vulnerability_information:
Hey team, I have discovered the CSTI vulnerability at NR single Plugin page leading to stored XSS. To plant the payload you need to publish new plugin using account having the payload inside its name. Below I show you the easiest way to reproduce this using a python script which creates the new plugin using the Plugins API. ###Steps to reproduce: 1) Sign into the NR app with "Admin" account 2) Change the account name to `xsstest{{'a'.constructor.prototype.charAt=[].join;$eval('x=alert(1)');}}` 3) Open attached python-script and change the `YOUR_LICENSE_KEY` to your own license key 4) Install the necessary python dependency with `sudo pip install requests` 5) Run the changed script with `python nr_new_plugin.py` 6) Navigate to NR Plugins and then to your new created plugin 7) Make sure the XSS payload is fired {F494473} ###Remediation The vulnerability exists because of using the Angular framework. Here is the HTML-code of plugin page: ```html ...

Published and supported by

PUBLISHER_NAME_HERE

  • About us  |  ... ``` As you can see, the `PUBLISHER_NAME_HERE` is inside the element which is the Angular-app container (`
    `, look at the `ng-app` attribute). It means that its content will be considered as Angular template so attacker can use the Angular template sandbox escape vulnerability to trigger an XSS here. The right way to fix this is not to return the user controlled data inside the Angular app container. All user controlled data should be retrieved using Angular built-in AJAX. As the immediate fix, you can just filter the `{}` signs. The vulnerability impact seems to be **higher than usual**, because after publishing this plugin, **every user from any account can be attacked**, when he visits the infected plugin page, not only users inside the attacker's account. So the impact here is up to the **arbitrary account takeover**. ## Impact Attacker can force victim to execute arbitrary JS-code.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hey team,

I have discovered the CSTI vulnerability at NR single Plugin page leading to stored XSS.

To plant the payload you need to publish new plugin using account having the payload inside its name. Below I show you the easiest way to reproduce this using a python script which creates the new plugin using the Plugins API.

Steps to reproduce:

1) Sign into the NR app with "Admin" account
2) Change the account name to xsstest{{'a'.constructor.prototype.charAt=[].join;$eval('x=alert(1)');}}
3) Open attached python-script and change the YOUR_LICENSE_KEY to your own license key
4) Install the necessary python dependency with sudo pip install requests
5) Run the changed script with python nr_new_plugin.py
6) Navigate to NR Plugins and then to your new created plugin
7) Make sure the XSS payload is fired

Remediation

The vulnerability exists because of using the Angular framework. Here is the HTML-code of plugin page:

...
<section class='span-4 last' ng-app='Plugins'>
<div class='branding-block clearfix'>
<p>Published and supported by</p>
<div class='logo'>
<img alt="Branding-default" height="44" src="/images/v4/platform/branding-default.png?e9181bf" width="44" />
</div>
<div class='information'>
<h1>PUBLISHER_NAME_HERE</h1>
<ul>
<li>
<a href='' target='_blank'>About us</a>
 | 
...

As you can see, the PUBLISHER_NAME_HERE is inside the element which is the Angular-app container (<section class='span-4 last' ng-app='Plugins'>, look at the ng-app attribute). It means that its content will be considered as Angular template so attacker can use the Angular template sandbox escape vulnerability to trigger an XSS here.

The right way to fix this is not to return the user controlled data inside the Angular app container. All user controlled data should be retrieved using Angular built-in AJAX. As the immediate fix, you can just filter the {} signs.

The vulnerability impact seems to be higher than usual, because after publishing this plugin, every user from any account can be attacked, when he visits the infected plugin page, not only users inside the attacker's account. So the impact here is up to the arbitrary account takeover.

Impact

Attacker can force victim to execute arbitrary JS-code.

activities.message: Hi @skavans ! Woah, I had to show my co-worker this XSS payload, that looks like a great catch! Since I'm going to take a flight today I may not be able to confirm it until tomorrow, but rest assured we're on it.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @skavans ! Woah, I had to show my co-worker this XSS payload, that looks like a great catch! Since I'm going to take a flight today I may not be able to confirm it until tomorrow, but rest assured we're on it.

activities.message:
Hey @scutler,

It looks like I was wrong a little with this
> The vulnerability impact seems to be higher than usual, because after publishing this plugin, every user from any account can be attacked, when he visits the infected plugin page, not only users inside the attacker's account. So the impact here is up to the arbitrary account takeover.

The payload doesn't fire at published plugin page (at least if I don't list it at Plugin Central). So it is usual `User to Admin XSS` (I realized that there is no admin account needed to plant the payload, because you can specify the infected publisher name at plugin publishing step, so it is enough to be a User to plant the infection).
activities.markdown_message:

It looks like I was wrong a little with this

The vulnerability impact seems to be higher than usual, because after publishing this plugin, every user from any account can be attacked, when he visits the infected plugin page, not only users inside the attacker's account. So the impact here is up to the arbitrary account takeover.

The payload doesn't fire at published plugin page (at least if I don't list it at Plugin Central). So it is usual User to Admin XSS (I realized that there is no admin account needed to plant the payload, because you can specify the infected publisher name at plugin publishing step, so it is enough to be a User to plant the infection).

activities.message:
Hi @skavans , can you provide a screenshot or details about where/how a normal user can specify the publisher name? I successfully reproduced this according to your original instructions but was unable to see where a normal user can modify that payload.

> you can specify the infected publisher name at plugin publishing step, so it is enough to be a User to plant the infection
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @skavans , can you provide a screenshot or details about where/how a normal user can specify the publisher name? I successfully reproduced this according to your original instructions but was unable to see where a normal user can modify that payload.

you can specify the infected publisher name at plugin publishing step, so it is enough to be a User to plant the infection

Hey @scutler,

The normal user can publish the apps. So he can specify the "Publisher name" at the publishing step.

The new name appears then at the published plugin page (where the payload is not executed):

And at the developer plugin page too, where the payload can be plant:

activities.message: I mean that before the plugin is published, the publisher name is account name. But when you publish it, you can specify the arbitrary publisher name, which will then appear at the vulnerable page.
activities.markdown_message: I mean that before the plugin is published, the publisher name is account name. But when you publish it, you can specify the arbitrary publisher name, which will then appear at the vulnerable page.

activities.message: I'm changing this over to triaged since I was able to reproduce it.
